Apr 12

Despite Health Concerns, Joel Embiid Will Become An NBA Superstar

Joel Embiid is the best center in the NBA.

This may sound hard to believe now, but in five years this statement will be true and Embiid will have more titles to his name besides just this one. They will include NBA All-Star and All-NBA appearances and maybe even an MVP.

Making this increasingly hard to believe is Joel Embiid’s impending surgery on his torn meniscus in his left knee. During his marvelous rookie season in which he opened many eyes, Embiid had many (including me) believing that he was the next big thing, but this injury has significantly put a damper on hopes for his superstar development.

This isn’t the first time he’s been injured, either. Ever since he burst on to the scene as a freshman at Kansas, Embiid has had three surgeries due to a stress fracture and now the recent torn meniscus. Big men with early injury history usually precede short and disappointing careers.

So what makes me so confident that Embiid will turn into a superstar? “The Process” has three defining traits that convince me that no matter what he experiences early in his career, by the end we will be looking at Hall of Fame level resume.

  1. He’s got the talent

To be a superstar, the most important aspect of any player is obviously their talent. A superstar needs to be able to take over a game, consistently perform at a high level, and do extraordinary things that normal players just can’t do.

Joel Embiid passes this test with flying colors. A peek at the basic box score shows over his 31 game season, he averaged 20.2 points, 7.8 rebounds, 2.1 assists, and 2.5 blocks, a mark that would rank second in the NBA had he qualified.

But these numbers don’t even tell the whole story. Since Embiid was on a minutes restriction he only played 25 minutes per game, thus deflating his per game stats. Per 36 minutes Embiid averaged 28.7 points per game, 11.1 rebounds, and 3.5 blocks.

To put that in perspective, 3 time All-Star and 2 time All-NBA player DeMarcus Cousins averaged 28.4 ppg, 11.7 rpg, and 1.4 bpg this year. And NBA Hall-of-Famer Hakeem Olajuwon averaged 24 ppg, 10.5 rpg, and 3.1 bpg in his MVP season. Don’t miscontrue this and believe Embiid is better than these players. But these metrics are incredibly promising for his future development.

His per-100 possessions stats (metrics which nullify pace) are eye-popping as well. He averaged an absurd38.8 points, 15.0 rebounds and 4.7 blocks during his 31 game rookie season. In fact, these averages that have only been matched by two of the greatest big men of all time: Karl Malone and Shaquille O’Neal. Through his first seven games he averaged 41.7 points, 15.1 rebounds and 5.2 blocks, numbers which have been matched by no one else in NBA history.

More importantly for such a young player, Embiid aces the eye test. He’s a 7'2 athletic specimen with jumping ability, length, and quickness. He can put the ball on the floor and blow by slower bigs and occasionally bring it up and go coast to coast. Almost unheard of for a 7-footer.

Embiid is also a dynamic post-up player, who has the strength to bully opponents and the finesse to shoot fadeaway jumpers and execute jump hooks. He can face up and play with his back to the basket. He uses advanced moves such as drop-steps, up-and-unders, and spin moves regularly and he can perform these moves on any defender no matter their size or athleticism. He simply needs to learn how to avoid turnovers and his post-up ability will be an extremely valuable tool in the future.

Embiid is the rare big that can score in the pick and roll just as well as he can in the pick and pop. While his shooting percentages haven’t yet caught up to his abilities, his 37 percent rate from three and 50 percent rate from two is nothing to sniff at, both solid starting points for the modern NBA center. Most bigs can really only do one or the other. The guys that pick-and-pop include Ryan Anderson, Dirk Nowitzki (currently), Kevin Love, and Paul Millsap. The guys that pick-and-roll include Dwight Howard, Clint Capela, Rudy Gobert, and DeAndre Jordan.

The few that can consistently do both are the truly elite modern scoring big men. Anthony Davis, DeMarcus Cousins, and Karl-Anthony Towns are arguably the three best scoring big men in the NBA currently, and all three have this ability. If Embiid develops the way his career so far suggests he will, he should comfortably average 27–28 ppg in his prime.

Defensively Embiid is a marvel, but he lacks polish. He is an unstoppable force at the rim and blocks almost everything in sight. He still leads all rookies in blocks despite only playing in 31 games this season. He held opponents to 41 percent shooting at the rim this year, which is the best in the league by 2 percent. To put that in context, that’s higher than the two Defensive Player of the Year candidates Rudy Gobert and Draymond Green hold opponents to 43.3 percent and 43.8 percent, respectively. This means Embiid might ALREADY be the best rim protector in the NBA, as a mere rookie.

Blocking shots isn’t all he can do on that end, either.

Embiid is one of the few bigs with the ability to defend the rim, and also step outside and defend the pick and roll. His quickness for a 7-footer is second to no one but Gobert, so he can play multiple different coverages. He can hedge, play ICE, and even switch occasionally and not get burned.

He can do everything on the court at an elite level except pass and avoid fouls, but in the latter years that should come along seeing as he hasn’t yet learned the intricacies of NBA defenses, considering that he was a very good passer and defender in college. Thanks to all these tools The Process clearly has the talent to turn heads and garner awards during his prime years.

2. He’s got the work ethic

To match an insane talent level, a superstar needs to have an insane work ethic. Getting better means constant hours in the gym and a relentlessness that is unmatched. All the great ones have this intensity, and Embiid does not lack in this aspect.

Embiid has worked tirelessly to improve his body. After coming into Kansas as a scrawny long, kid, Embiid has transformed himself into a physical monster. He buried himself in the weight room at Kansas and in Philly, and it has worked greatly in his favor, as now Embiid has the strength to bully the majority of centers in the NBA. When he learns to consistently harness this, he will be unstoppable.

And Embiid has also quickly increased his skill set every year since he began playing basketball at age 16. His first organized basketball experience came as a JV player as a junior in high school, and as a senior he transferred to a smaller school and averaged 13 points per game. His only high school highlights were of him finishing a lob or blocking some poor kid’s shot.

He has developed rapidly since then. In college he could post up, he could pass, and he could play high level defense. His offensive game improved to the point where he could be counted on to get buckets in crunch time, which was impressive considering he was so raw in high school.

And he will only continue to get better. During his rehab time last year Embiid sought out skills trainer Drew Hanlen to improve his post game and his jump shot. He had to fly out to an elite training facility in Qatar to do this, and the results have been phenomenal. Embiid looks as fluid as a point guard and has the ball-handling abilities to match. His jump shot looks smooth and unblockable, and it’s clear his hours and hours in the gym have paid off.

This is all due to his work ethic and insatiable desire to succeed. He has gotten better and better every year and his skill set has expanded exponentially. Everyday, grueling workouts with the NBA’s best trainers give me a good reason to believe he has the diligence and aspiration to be one of the NBA’s greats.

3. He’s got the intangibles

Joel Embiid has one of the most vibrant personalities that we’ve seen in recent NBA history. He’s an outgoing guy, and his charm and charisma make him one of the most likable professional athletes in the nation. He’s always smiling at reporters, giving hilarious interviews, and being a goofball at all times.

Exhibit A:

Despite what you may think, this matters. Almost every truly memorable superstar has a defining character trait and many have multiple. Jordan was a psycho competitor and a trash talker. Kobe was the same to a lesser degree. LeBron is an overpowering leader with at times a playful countenance. Magic was a smiling, upbeat leader who pushed his teammates through encouragement. All four were great with the media and were very marketable.

The Process is the NBA’s resident Twitter champion, as his account includes more hilarity than every other NBA player’s accounts combined. He flirts with Rihanna, he promotes his All-Star campaign, and he even makes jokes about his injury history. Want more proof that he rules Twitter? Just look at his avi, which was chosen after teammate TJ McConnell hit a game winner against the New York Knicks.

Embiid is one of the few young stars with a truly unique personality. His radiant smile and his constant antics make him a lovable off-court personality so therefore he’s very marketable. Not many big men are marketable, so Embiid’s shining characteristics make him one of the select few.

However, his intangibles don’t stop there. They include characteristics that will actually help the Sixers win games. Embiid is well-renowned among the Sixers organization as a student of the game. Sports Illustrated’s Lee Jenkins describes him as one who “comes across as a de facto scout”. He can analyze different opponent tendencies, discuss team strategies, and break down the decisions of general managers. He knows the game inside and out.

One of the greatest assets a team can have is a leader who has a genuine passion for the game. A leader that has obsessed with learning and improving will push his teammates to get better and not to settle for less than winning. A leader such as this is incredibly valuable, and he will lead a team far in the playoffs.

Embiid even showed how valuable he was to the team this year. According to @NBA_Math on Twitter, per as-of-yet-unreleased FATS calculator, the Philadelphia 76ers played like a 49.9-win team with Joel Embiid, and a 27.7-win team without him this season. A 50 win team in this season would’ve been third in the Eastern Conference. And Embiid is JUST A ROOKIE. Doubting the Process would be downright foolish.

What about Embiid’s injuries?

So how can Embiid avoid this injury bug that has plagued the careers of many promising big men before? What makes his career any different than that of Greg Oden, Yao Ming or Sam Bowie?

Embiid has a weapon none of those guys had: an elite jump shot.

Due to this immensely important skill, Embiid won’t have to put as much pressure on his lower body as his career progresses, as he has a lot of finesse to his game. He can shoot the ball from the mid-range and the three, and although he may not be all he could be, an Embiid-turned-Dirk Nowitzki will still be an impressive player. That’s a guy that any NBA team would love having, and his career will last longer because of it.

Trust the Process
Joel Embiid wasn’t as much born as he was artificially hatched out of a genetically modified basketball.16winsaring.com

And there are physical things he can alter in games to prevent these injuries. They are completely fixable.

His landings are consistently problematic. He lands with his knees caved in, which is horrible for the tendons and could’ve initially led to his stress fracture, the first of his injuries. And furthermore this could’ve led to him favoring the left knee at time, causing his meniscus to tear.

When big men land, they have to accept more force on their knees than the average sized player, making foot injuries common on even simple moves. Couple this with bad landing mechanics and that’s why we have so many sad stories of big men never reaching their sky-high potential.

This video below further expounds on it:

Now, to believe he could truly get back to peak physical form this would require us assuming the doctors and physical therapists around Embiid would get him to fix his landing mechanics and he would be all in on the rehab.

You should have no problem believing this.

The 76ers have an impressive medical staff which include certified Sports Medicine Surgeon Christopher C. Dodson as their Head Team Physician and Bradford S. Tucker, their Assistant Team Physician who specializes in knee cartilage restoration procedures. These highly credentialed men have healed Embiid before and they’ll do it again, as long as he’s completely dialed in. Since Embiid is their franchise player, it is in their best interest to make sure he is as healthy as possible and they will dedicate their summer to it.

And he will be. Embiid has gone through this before and he knows what it takes. His extreme love for the game will cause him not to want to miss any more time on the court, and his experience in rehab before (which was not positive), will motivate him to fight through and complete the procedure with focus and maturity.

Conclusion

Face it, folks. If you’re looking for the next big thing, look no further than Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. You better trust The Process because the heir to the throne is a Cameroonian behemoth who is about to dominate the NBA for the next decade.
